Headline.Para: A TV Marketer Puts Unique Twist on Manhattan Townhouse Sales Pitch; Anand Khubani has covered the front of his Upper East Side townhouse with a 60-foot high screen displaying a new design for the building

LeadPara.Para: The house has features of a classic Upper East Side townhouse: A limestone facade with a grand entrance, bronze doors, stone columns and a cornice.
But when the wind blows the limestone ripples in the breeze.

TailParas.Para: That's because the facade actually is an elaborate, 60-foot-high printed screen, strapped to an unlovely and mostly unadorned red brick building on East 66th Street in Manhattan.

It was the idea of Anand Khubani, a New Jersey businessman who specializes in "as-seen-on-TV" marketing. He was searching for a new way to showcase a Manhattan townhouse that he has been having trouble selling.
A few years earlier, Mr. Khubani dabbled in the Manhattan real-estate market, paying cash for two townhouses that he has been unable to sell as the Manhattan townhouse market weakened.

In 2015, he paid $14 million for the 20-foot-wide building at 56 East 66th St. The original neo-Grec brownstone facade was part of a row of 10 similar houses designed in 1877. Decades later, some of these simple but sturdy facades were replaced with far more ornate facades in the Beaux Arts and neoclassical styles, with arched windows, columns, and balconies.

Number 56 survived intact until 1935, when a new front was built, with plain red brick and wide casement windows. It was converted into 10 rental apartments. In 1991, a doctor's office was carved out of the ground floor and basement.
The entire block was part of the Upper East Side Historic District designated in 1981.

Mr. Khubani, the founder of IdeaVillage Products Corp., whose products include the MicroTouch Max personal hair trimmer, said he had a simple plan: Rebuild the house inside and out, with the approval of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

In its decision, the commission said the Khubani house had been "highly altered," and found that the new design was "in keeping with classical vocabulary of high-style residences" throughout the surrounding historic district.

After the commission sanctioned a redesign of the house, prices slid as townhouse sales slowed from the peak in 2014, said Lisa Simonsen, a Douglas Elliman broker, who is marketing the house along with Kristin Lukic, also of Douglas Elliman.

Mr. Khubani decided to put the building on the market as is, including plans for a new single-family townhouse that were approved in August 2015. A buyer, either a future homeowner or investor, would have to spend 12 to 15 months and millions of dollars to complete the vision and transform it into a single family mansion, Ms. Simonsen noted.

Mr. Khubani listed the un-renovated house with Ms. Simonsen for $19.95 million in 2015, soon after the plans were approved, and eventually cut the listing price in stages to $13.95 million in January, just below what he paid for it.
He said he came up with the idea for the screen on the front of the building out of frustration that buyers had trouble imagining what a finished townhouse might look like.
"The market had been a little quiet," Mr. Khubani said. "Rather than invest in developing it right away, the idea was to give the potential customer a vision."

The screen showcases the ability to create an updated limestone-and-glass townhouse "in one of the most coveted locations on the Upper East Side," he said. Other houses in the area have facades that can't be altered because they have been landmarked.

"What is there now is nicer to look at than what was formerly there," said Matthew Lesser, a broker at Leslie J. Garfield, who is listing a neoclassical townhouse that is now an apartment building two doors down for $16 million. It was listed for $20 million in 2016.
Inside 56 East 66th is a jumble of rooms with broken and fallen plaster and test holes cut into the foundation.

Under the city-approved plans, the entry level would be raised to create a street-level entrance. That would raise the height of the cellar beneath, while keeping the ceilings of the parlor level in excess of 12 feet, Ms. Simonsen said. The rear of the building would be rebuilt and extended with glass walls. The facade would have more light than many older townhouses.

In 2013, Mr. Khubani paid $6.35 million for a 15-foot wide house at 48 East 64th St., and spent $4 million renovating it. It was listed with Ms. Simonsen for nearly $18 million in 2015, and the price has since been repeatedly reduced. It was listed at $12.9 million in January.
Instead of selling, Ms. Simonsen said, Mr. Khubani rented the house out for three years.
Mr. Khubani said he originally had considered moving in to each house, but then changed his mind, an experience that left his investments "heavy in real estate."
He said he is no longer in the market for townhouses. "At the appropriate time I will look for a condo," he said.
